options.text: Configure the execution schedule and session host lifecycle management settings.

The function will run at the selected hours on the selected days of the week. For example, selecting the times 8 AM, 9 AM, 10 AM, 11 AM, 12 PM, 1 PM, 2 PM, 3 PM, 4 PM, and 5 PM along with Monday-Friday will run the function every hour from 8 AM to 5 PM on weekdays only. The schedule uses the timezone selected in the 'Session Hosts' blade.

options.text: To prevent multiple function apps from running simultaneously and potentially causing API throttling, you can stagger the execution time by setting different start minutes for each deployment. The function will execute at the specified minute within each scheduled hour.

elements.name: scheduleMinuteOffset
elements.label: Start Minute
elements.toolTip: The minute within each hour when the function will execute. For example, if set to 15, the function will run at :15 of each scheduled hour (8:15, 9:15, etc.). Set to 0 to run at the top of each hour. Use different values across deployments to stagger execution.

options.text: Session hosts are automatically replaced when a new image version is available. You can optionally specify a delay period before triggering replacements after a new image is published to allow for testing.

elements.name: replaceSessionHostOnNewImageVersionDelayDays

elements.name: allowImageVersionRollback
elements.label: Allow Image Version Rollback
elements.toolTip: When enabled, allows session hosts to be replaced even if their current image version is newer than the latest available version. When disabled (recommended), prevents unintended rollbacks to older images.

options.text: <u>Replacement Mode Configuration</u>
SideBySide: Adds new hosts before deleting old ones (zero downtime, higher cost during updates). DeleteFirst: Deletes idle hosts before adding replacements (lower cost, temporary capacity reduction).

elements.name: replacementMode
elements.label: Replacement Mode
elements.toolTip: Strategy for replacing session hosts during image updates.

elements.name: drainGracePeriodHours
elements.label: Drain Grace Period for Active Sessions (hours)
elements.toolTip: Session hosts WITH active sessions will remain in drain mode for this duration before deletion. This protects user sessions.

elements.name: minimumDrainMinutes
elements.label: Minimum Drain Time for Idle Hosts (minutes)
elements.toolTip: Session hosts with ZERO sessions require only this minimum drain time before deletion. With hourly scheduling: 0=current run, 1-60=next run (~1hr), 61-120=second run (~2hrs). Values >0 provide safety buffer for API lag and race conditions.

elements.name: minimumCapacityPercentage
elements.label: Minimum Capacity Percentage (DeleteFirst mode)
elements.toolTip: Minimum percentage of target capacity to maintain during DeleteFirst mode. Prevents over-deletion and maintains service availability. Only applies when replacementMode is DeleteFirst.

elements.name: maxDeletionsPerCycle
elements.label: Max Deletions Per Cycle (DeleteFirst mode)
elements.toolTip: Maximum number of hosts to delete per execution cycle in DeleteFirst mode. Prevents too-aggressive scale-down. Only applies when replacementMode is DeleteFirst.

elements.name: targetSessionHostCount
elements.label: Target Session Host Count
elements.toolTip: The target number of session hosts to maintain. Set to 0 for auto-detect mode: automatically maintains current count during each replacement cycle, allowing manual scaling between image updates.

elements.name: maxDeploymentBatchSize
elements.label: Maximum Deployment Batch Size
elements.toolTip: Maximum number of hosts to deploy per run (ceiling constraint).

options.text: <u>Device Cleanup</u>

Device Cleanup Automation Overview

Device cleanup automation removes stale Entra ID and/or Intune device records when session hosts are deleted. This is especially important when session hosts are Entra ID-joined (i.e., not joined to Active Directory Domain Services or Entra Domain Services) to prevent accumulation of orphaned device records.

Required Permissions:
This feature requires a User-Assigned Managed Identity with the following Microsoft Graph API permissions:
  • 'Directory.ReadWrite.All' - Required for Entra ID device deletion
  • 'DeviceManagementManagedDevices.ReadWrite.All' - Required for Intune device deletion
Important Note: Device.ReadWrite.All does NOT allow device deletion despite its name. You must use Directory.ReadWrite.All for Entra ID device cleanup.

Ensure these permissions are granted to the user-assigned managed identity before deployment.

Important: If you enable either cleanup option below, you must select a pre-existing User-Assigned Managed Identity in the Infrastructure section that has been granted the appropriate Microsoft Graph API permissions.

Air-Gapped Cloud Limitations:
Intune is not currently available in Air-Gapped Clouds such as Azure Government Secret and Azure Government Top Secret. In these environments, the Intune Device Cleanup option will be automatically disabled, and the 'DeviceManagementManagedDevices.ReadWrite.All' permission is not required.

elements.toolTip: The minimum starting index for hostname numbering. In SideBySide mode, all new hosts start from this number. In DeleteFirst mode, this is used as a fallback when deploying more hosts than were deleted (e.g., 10 to create host10, host11, etc.).

options.text:
Zero Trust Networking for Function Apps and Azure Resources

This section configures network-level security controls to enforce Zero Trust Architecture principles for the Session Host Replacer function app and its dependencies (storage accounts, key vaults).

Private Endpoints: Enable private connectivity to Platform as a Service (PaaS) resources (Blob Storage, File Storage, and Key Vaults) by assigning private IP addresses from your virtual network. This removes public internet exposure and routes traffic over the Microsoft backbone network.

Virtual Network Integration: The function app requires outbound virtual network integration to communicate privately with resources protected by private endpoints. This requires a dedicated subnet with Microsoft.Web/serverFarms delegation.

Both features require Private DNS Zones for proper name resolution. For centralized DNS management in hub-and-spoke topologies, refer to the Private Link hub-and-spoke deployment guidance linked below.

link.label: Microsoft Learn | Private Link Deployment in a Hub and Spoke Network

options.text: When deploying function app zero trust networking, you must select the subnet and Private DNS Zones required for DNS resolution. The available virtual networks are dynamically filtered according to the regions specified for the resource types in earlier configuration screens. The drop-down menus will present only the virtual networks, subnets, and Private DNS Zones that match your prior selections, ensuring that you can choose the appropriate resources for your Zero Trust implementation.
<u>Subnets</u>

options.text: <u>Private DNS Zones</u>

To connect privately with your function app and private endpoints, you need DNS records. We recommend that you integrate your function app private endpoints with private DNS zones. If you select the checkbox below, you'll be asked to select the appropriate Private DNS Zone for each resource type deployed by this solution and the deployment will automatically create the Private DNS integration when creating the private endpoints. Alternatively, you can assign policies to private endpoints to automatically register the endpoints with the appropriate private DNS zones. Uncheck the box below if that is the method you are using.

options.text: There are several types of encryption available for your managed disks including Azure Disk Storage Server-Side Encryption (SSE), Encryption at Host (EAH), and Confidential disk encryption (when the Confidential VM security type is selected).
• Azure Disk Storage Server-Side Encryption is always enabled and automatically encrypts your data stored on Azure managed disks (OS and data disks) when persisting on the storage clusters.
• Encryption at host enhances Azure Disk Storage Server-Side Encryption to ensure that all temp disks and disk caches are encrypted at rest and flow encrypted to the Storage clusters.

elements.name: encryptionAtHost
elements.label: Encryption At Host
elements.toolTip: Check to enable Encryption At Host

options.text: The 'Encryption At Host' feature is not registered in your subscription. Follow the guidance at this link to enable the feature and restart the deployment.

• Confidential disk encryption binds disk encryption keys to the virtual machine's TPM and makes the protected disk content accessible only to the VM. The TPM and VM guest state is always encrypted in attested code using keys released by a secure protocol that bypasses the hypervisor and host operating system. Currently only available for the OS disk. Encryption at host may be used for other disks on a Confidential VM in addition to Confidential Disk Encryption.

elements.name: confidentialVMOSDiskEncryption
elements.label: Confidential OS Disk Encryption
elements.toolTip: Check to enable Confidential VM disk encryption

options.text: Azure Dedicated Host is a service that provides physical servers able to host one or more virtual machines assigned to one Azure subscription. Dedicated hosts are the same physical servers used in our data centers, provided instead as a directly accessible hardware resource.

In some environments it is required to have a dedicated Azure Host to isolate Compute. This is most common in IL5 type environments. Selecting this option will ensure the VMs are deployed to pre-existing Dedicated Host(s). Click this box for more information.
